Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 1, as this is a civil action involving claims for damages under Massachusetts law.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 2, as the property is located within Worcester County.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, where a landlord’s actions or inactions interfere substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises, the landlord violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, \u00a7 127L.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also contravenes his statutory obligation under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, § 127L to maintain sanitary conditions and eliminate pest infestations.

*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (195.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14 and supporting case law such as *Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (1950), as well as *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994), Defendant’s breach entitles Plaintiff to recover actual damages, costs, and attorney’s fees.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (195.support_reasoning: The opinion in Dartmouth v. Silva is an equitable nuisance case brought by a town seeking injunctive relief to abate flooding of public ways. The court discusses the town’s standing and right to obtain an injunction; it does not interpret Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14, nor does it address a tenant’s statutory right to recover actual damages, costs, or attorney’s fees. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the remedial proposition claimed.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (195.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff grounds its right to relief on the existence of a nuisance… A town is under a duty to keep its ways in repair and is liable to travellers injured by reason of a breach of that duty… The obstruction and diverting of the watercourse in the present case have caused water to ‘flow or spill over the town ways.’… The plaintiff should not be required to wait until it has incurred such expense or liability before it can have a remedy.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14 and supporting case law such as *Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (1950), as well as *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994), Defendant’s breach entitles Plaintiff to recover actual damages, costs, and attorney’s fees.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the remedies available for a landlord’s breach of G. L. c. 186, § 14, including actual damages, costs, and attorney’s fees. In this opinion, the SJC expressly holds that, if the housing authority is found to have breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment under § 14, the tenants will be entitled to judgment along with injunctive relief, costs, and reasonable attorney’s fees. That directly supports using this case as authority for the remedial aspect of § 14 referenced in the proposition.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs’ right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: The breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment also violates legal principles established in Massachusetts caselaw, including *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (articulating landlord obligations under the implied warranty of habitability) and *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (allowing recovery for emotional distress in such circumstances).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a concurring/dissenting opinion and deals with implied warranty of habitability and statutory/code-based landlord duties, not with the covenant of quiet enjoyment or emotional distress. While Hemingway is indeed a foundational Massachusetts case on the implied warranty of habitability, this passage does not connect that doctrine to the covenant of quiet enjoyment or to emotional‑distress damages. Thus, using this citation to say that a breach of quiet enjoyment violates legal principles established in Hemingway overstates what this opinion supports.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment also violates legal principles established in Massachusetts caselaw, including *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (articulating landlord obligations under the implied warranty of habitability) and *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (allowing recovery for emotional distress in such circumstances).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties the covenant of quiet enjoyment and G.L. c. 186, § 14 to the broader Massachusetts landlord-tenant remedial framework developed in Hemingway and related cases, and it squarely holds that emotional distress damages are recoverable as “actual and consequential damages” for interference with quiet enjoyment. The court explains that § 14 was intended to expand common-law quiet-enjoyment damages and that “all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic” are within its scope, thereby authorizing recovery for emotional distress in this landlord-tenant context. Although the court ultimately vacates the specific $10,000 quiet-enjoyment award as duplicative, the reasoning clearly recognizes emotional distress as a proper element of damages under Massachusetts quiet enjoyment principles.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. We have noted that this provision was intended to expand the damages recoverable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case… Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14…”
